markdown: <::attestation: Signature Signature: legible Readable Text: File A handwritten signature in the center of the image.::> Carl Byoir & Associates, Inc. MAR 1 3 1978 Carolyn Walden, Director TV, Radio, Film Department February 9, 1978 Ms. Julia Child "The French Chef" c/o WGBH-TV 125 Western Avenue Boston, Massachusetts 02134 Dear Ms. Child: Boy...do you have a lot of fans! Unfortunately for me, a lot of them are members of the Sugar Association which is a client of mine. I say unfortunately because in the last month or so it seems I've heard from each and every one of the Association's members. The reason? It seems in a recent broadcast you mentioned that you were about to use cane sugar as an ingredient...instead of beet sugar...because of its superior qualities. Well, as you'll soon see from the enclosed materials, the authorities say there is no difference between the two. That, indeed, sugar -- whether refined from sugar beets or from sugar cane -- is the same sugar. I guess (to paraphrase Gertrude Stein) you could say that "sugar...is sugar ...is sugar." This should serve as an explanation for all that I've sent. I hope you find the material both interesting and informative. And if I can be of any additional help, please don't hesitate to call me collect in New York. <::attestation: Signature Signed Signature: legible (Carolyn Walder) Readable Text: Cordially, A handwritten signature appears below the typed word "Cordially," positioned in the lower-left quadrant of the image.::> (more) 380 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017 · Telephone (212) 986-6100

Carolyn Walden, Director TV, Radio, Film Department
Ms. Julia Child "The French Chef" c/o WGBH-TV 125 Western Avenue Boston, Massachusetts 02134

Dear Ms. Child: Boy...do you have a lot of fans! Unfortunately for me, a lot of them are members of the Sugar Association which is a client of mine. I say unfortunately because in the last month or so it seems I've heard from each and every one of the Association's members. The reason? It seems in a recent broadcast you mentioned that you were about to use cane sugar as an ingredient...instead of beet sugar...because of its superior qualities. Well, as you'll soon see from the enclosed materials, the authorities say there is no difference between the two. That, indeed, sugar -- whether refined from sugar beets or from sugar cane -- is the same sugar. I guess (to paraphrase Gertrude Stein) you could say that "sugar...is sugar ...is sugar." This should serve as an explanation for all that I've sent. I hope you find the material both interesting and informative. And if I can be of any additional help, please don't hesitate to call me collect in New York.

<::attestation: Signature Signed Signature: legible (Carolyn Walder) Readable Text: Cordially, A handwritten signature appears below the typed word "Cordially," positioned in the lower-left quadrant of the image.::>
380 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017 · Telephone (212) 986-6100
